title: 104_hr1497
content: The Act titled "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" revises the limitation on deduction of policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The deduction for any taxable year cannot exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of life insurance. The deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies is amended by the Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995." The deduction for any taxable year cannot exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of life insurance company taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. The deduction cannot exceed 90% of policyholder dividends or 30% of company taxable income, with a minimum limit of $35,000,000. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they possess at least 80% of total stock. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they possess at least 80% of total stock voting power or value. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they possess at least 80% of total stock voting power or value. Section 809 of the Code is repealed. The Act "Insurance Tax Fairness and Small Insurance Company Economic Growth Act of 1995" amends the deduction limitation for policyholder dividends by mutual life insurance companies. Stock life insurance companies are treated as mutual if they possess at least 80% of total stock voting power or value. Section 809 of the Code is repealed, along with amendments to sections 807(a)(2)(B) and 807(b)(1)(B) regarding policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest. The Code is amended to adjust the policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest in various sections. The Code is amended to adjust policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest in different sections, including changes to sections 812(b)(3), 817(c), and 842(c). These amendments will apply to taxable years, with exceptions outlined. The Code is amended to adjust policyholders' share of tax-exempt interest in different sections, including changes to section 842(c) by striking paragraph (3) and redesignating paragraph (4) as paragraph (3). The amendments made by this section shall apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1994, with exceptions outlined. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. It does not affect the application of section 809(f) for years before January 1, 1995. Capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2). Limitation on loss carrybacks for life insurance companies under section 808(b)(2) of the Code: Capital losses after December 31, 1994, cannot be carried back to taxable years before January 1, 1995. Small life insurance companies are exempt from capitalizing certain policy acquisition expenses as per an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This exemption applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 1994. Additionally, there is a sense of Congress regarding the use of increased revenues. The Congress believes that any revenue increase from the amendments should be used for deficit reduction, tax incentives for small life insurance companies, and programs benefiting children's nutrition, education, housing, and family support.
